description_abstract: Acid/Base characterizations of metal oxide surfaces are often used to explain their catalytic behavior.  However, the vast majority of these studies have been performed on powders or supported oxides, and there is very little information available in the literature on the interaction of acid/base probe molecules with well-defined oxide surfaces of known coordination geometry and oxidation state.  The well-defined, single crystal surfaces of Cu<sub>2</sub>O (111), SnO<sub>2</sub> (110), and Cr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (10<u>1</u>2) were investigated for their acid/base properties by the interactions between the probe molecules and the well-defined surface features.  The adsorption of NH<sub>3</sub> at cation sites was used to characterize the Lewis acidity of SnO<sub>2</sub> (110) and Cu<sub>2</sub>O (111) surfaces.  The adsorption of CO<sub>2</sub>, a standard acidic probe molecule, was used to characterize the Lewis basicity of the oxygen anions on SnO<sub>2</sub> (110), Cu<sub>2</sub>O (111) , and Cr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (10<u>1</u>2) surfaces.  BF<sub>3</sub>, while not a standard probe molecule, has been tested as a probe of the Lewis basicity of the oxygen anions on SnO<sub>2</sub> (110) and Cr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (10<u>1</u>2).       By studying probe molecules on well-defined metal oxide surfaces with known coordination geometry and oxidation state, an overall evaluation of NH<sub>3</sub>, CO<sub>2</sub>, and BF<sub>3</sub> as probe molecules can be made using the surfaces studied.  NH<sub>3</sub> probed differences in Lewis acidity of Sn cations on SnO<sub>2</sub> (110), which had differences in coordination environments and oxidation states.  But, NH<sub>3</sub> adsorption failed to provide any direct information on differences in Lewis acidity of Cu cations in different local coordination geometries on Cu<sub>2</sub>O (111).  CO<sub>2</sub> is a poor probe of the Lewis basicity of oxygen anions on the metal oxide surfaces studied here.  CO<sub>2</sub> does not strongly adsorb to either SnO<sub>2</sub> (110) or Cu<sub>2</sub>O (111).  On Cr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (10<u>1</u>2), CO<sub>2</sub> does interact with oxygen sites but in two different coordinations, which vary with surface condition, making a comparison of basicity difficult.  In the cases studied here, CO<sub>2</sub> either does not adsorb, or it does not provide a clear set of results that can be related simply to Lewis basicity.  BF<sub>3</sub> seems to be a much better probe of the Lewis basicity than CO<sub>2</sub> for the well-defined metal oxide surfaces studied here.  On SnO<sub>2</sub> (110) and Cr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (10<u>1</u>2), the boron atom of BF<sub>3</sub> directly interacts with oxygen sites by accepting their electrons.  BF<sub>3</sub> thermal desorption seems to provide a direct measure of the Lewis basicity of different surface oxygen species as long as they are thermally-stable in vacuum.
